intro: Verbesina allophylla, commonly known as the narrowleaf beggar-ticks, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and opposite leaf arrangement. The plant typically grows in moist to wet habitats such as swamps, marshes, and along stream banks. Its leaves are narrow and serrated, while its flowers are yellow and produce small, fluffy seeds that are dispersed by the wind. Verbesina allophylla is known for its ability to thrive in wetland environments and is often found in areas with rich, organic soil.
